The lazy admin used the same prime twice when generating RSA keys. Can you exploit this slip to recover the original message from 186811817419561379619508985596509273028610116089267217564854043095307582894501119868322210669175746243750846536058747074406808125090518410144147000328229?

The flag format is flag{...}
n=6637005158158109146449410315701488798862812064989198107610274644919820646053681583572614629977534466748563354341227123128944790630339012891568792408309969, e=2172038251405009464896168479045377890139839716640692570132936736154663680619786507591762355489382735300472756535663366343824799979837705866665320947745149

---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{80z786zn}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 186811817419561379619508985596509273028610116089267217564854043095307582894501119868322210669175746243750846536058747074406808125090518410144147000328229
vulnerability: repeated primes
hint: The RSA modulus n is a perfect square. This often indicates a repeated prime usage vulnerability.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=6637005158158109146449410315701488798862812064989198107610274644919820646053681583572614629977534466748563354341227123128944790630339012891568792408309969, e=2172038251405009464896168479045377890139839716640692570132936736154663680619786507591762355489382735300472756535663366343824799979837705866665320947745149
extra_info: p=81467816701800160286154874570522518979967068326895322830748404544605237962313, q=81467816701800160286154874570522518979967068326895322830748404544605237962313, Ï†(n)=6637005158158109146449410315701488798862812064989198107610274644919820646053518647939211029656962156999422309303267188992290999984677516082479581932385344
subtype: repeated_prime_usage
